description: From Middle English vermyn, vermyne, from Old French vermine, from Vulgar Latin *verminum (“vermin”), collective noun formed from Latin vermis (“worm”). See also worm.

nouns.description: vermin (countable and uncountable, plural vermin or vermins)

entries.meaning: (countable or uncountable) Any one of various common types of small insects or animals which cause harm and annoyance. [from c. 1300]
examples: The area was plagued by all sorts of vermin: fleas, lice, mice, and rats to name a few.

entries.meaning: (countable or uncountable) Animals that prey on game, such as foxes or weasels.
(countable or uncountable) Obnoxious, or mean and offensive person or people. [from 1560s]
examples: Bring these vermin to the Palace of Justice.
